Award.AwardTitle: Federal Aviation Administration's Aviation Weather Research Program (FAA AWA) support of the National Center for Atmospheric Research

POR.DRECONTENT:
The FAA has been directing NCAR for more than three decades to conduct research and development activities with a particular focus on advancing the scientific understanding of atmospheric processes that lead to aviation weather hazards and developing diagnosis, nowcasting and forecasting capabilities to enhance the safety and efficiency of general aviation and commercial air transportation across the United States airspace as well as globally.

 

Development of useful aviation applications requires a strong connection between NCAR’s work and the needs of aviators.  End-user requirements are considered at each step along the development path.  NCAR’s work tends to be heavily oriented toward real-time operational systems and this focus leads to an emphasis on algorithm development, specialized graphical displays, systems engineering, operational demonstrations, and the associated scientific validations and user-oriented evaluations.

 

NCAR’s current research and development efforts emphasize aviation weather hazards associated with summer and winter storms, atmospheric turbulence, ground and inflight icing, ceiling, and visibility.  New and enhanced prediction capabilities are regularly transitioned into operations at NOAA to provide state-of-the-art weather hazard guidance to the aviation industry through tools accessible at the Aviation Weather Center.  Moreover, NCAR is supporting the FAA in the development of next-generation dissemination standards and evaluation of prototypes.

 

Notable high-impact achievements during the recent period of an Interagency Agreement between the FAA and NSF included:

  • Development of the aerosol-aware microphysics package in the Weather Research and Forecasting (WRF) model and getting it into the operational weather prediction code at NOAA’s National Centers for Environmental Prediction (NCEP).  In particular, the prediction of clouds and when they begin to rain has been improved through a more realistic representation of the tiny particles called aerosols that become water droplets and/or ice particles than any preceding method used in operational weather models.
  • Distribution of an algorithm developed to capture the eddy dissipation rate (EDR) of atmospheric turbulence in real time using data accessed from an aircraft’s avionics system.  The algorithm has been packaged and documented for easy distribution and implementation by airline operators and aircraft manufacturers.  The resulting in-situ EDR data is key for providing objective information about current atmospheric turbulence hazards and also for calibration of turbulence prediction algorithms.
  • Significantly enhanced understanding of convectively induced turbulence.  Detailed case studies and high-resolution simulations have demonstrated that turbulence experienced by aircraft outside of clouds (i.e., perceived as clear air turbulence) may actually be caused by convective storms possibly a significant distance away.  Insights gained from these analyses will be utilized to improve turbulence guidance for the aviation industry.
  • Development, evaluation, and implementation of a convective storm prediction capability for strategic air traffic management through collaboration between the Massachusetts Institute of Technology Lincoln Laboratory (MIT/LL), NOAA Earth System Research Laboratory (ESRL), and NCAR.  This real-time prototype thunderstorm guidance product is heavily relied upon in today’s commercial air transport operations by airline dispatchers and FAA traffic managers to anticipate convective weather impacts several hours in advance.  Given the demonstrated quantitative benefits provided by the prototype system, the FAA is moving forward with a formal acquisition process.
  • Detailed insights about lightning impacts on airport and airline ground operations leading to better guidance.  Comprehensive observations, simulations, and analyses were conducted to quantify the safety risk of outdoor personnel servicing aircraft during nearby and overhead thunderstorms, measure the delays incurred due to safety procedures implemented to protect people from injury, and determine the operational “sweet spot” balancing personnel safety and operational efficiency.  Insights gained through this work will be used to develop improved outdoor personnel safety guidance for the aviation industry.
  • Global interoperability of next generation of aviation weather capabilities.  Substantial work has been conducted to lay the foundation for international standards of data exchange to enable sharing of weather-related information across the global aviation industry.
  • Education and outreach activities.  NCAR continues to be very active facilitating aviation industry forums to educate stakeholders about emerging weather guidance capabilities and discussing needed new requirements.
